content.title: Angiosome-Directed Revascularization
content.summary: Angiosome-directed revascularization targets the artery directly feeding the wound location based on the angiosome concept. This approach may improve wound healing outcomes in patients with tissue loss by ensuring blood flow reaches the affected tissue.
content.definition: A revascularization strategy that targets the source artery supplying the angiosome containing the wound or ischemic tissue, based on the principle that each foot region has a specific arterial supply

angiosome_concept.definition: A three-dimensional block of tissue (skin, subcutaneous, muscle, bone) supplied by a single source artery
angiosome_concept.origin: Described by Taylor and Palmer in 1987
angiosome_concept.application: Extended to foot and leg by Attinger for wound healing

direct.definition: Revascularization of the artery directly feeding the wound angiosome
direct.example: Posterior tibial revascularization for plantar heel wound

indirect.definition: Revascularization of a different tibial artery with collateral supply to wound
indirect.example: Anterior tibial revascularization for heel wound (relies on collaterals)

choke_vessels.function: May allow indirect revascularization to heal wounds

findings: Improved wound healing with direct revascularization

arguments: Pedal arch patency may be more important

clinical_evidence.current_consensus: Consider angiosome targeting when technically feasible, but patency of any tibial vessel is better than none

toe.direct: Variable; typically posterior tibial or anterior tibial
toe.note: Depends on which digital branch supplies affected toe

preoperative_planning: Assess target vessel patency on imaging
Consider both direct and indirect options

decision_making.direct_preferable_when: Target vessel is accessible and of reasonable quality
decision_making.indirect_acceptable_when: Direct vessel occluded or heavily calcified, indirect has better target

endovascular_vs_surgical.surgical: Bypass to available target; graft length considerations

limitations.multilevel_disease: Inflow must be adequate regardless of angiosome
limitations.pedal_arch: Intact pedal arch may allow indirect revascularization success

content.statement: Angiosome-Directed Revascularization is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Pad that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Angiosome-Directed Revascularization helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Angiosome-Directed Revascularization include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Angiosome-Directed Revascularization.

definition.@value: Revascularization strategy targeting the source artery supplying the angiosome containing the wound

learning_objectives: Define the angiosome concept as applied to the foot
Map foot wound locations to their source arteries
Apply angiosome principles to revascularization planning
Recognize limitations and evidence supporting this approach
clinical_pearls: Heel wounds: posterior tibial (direct) or peroneal (indirect)
Dorsal foot wounds: anterior tibial / dorsalis pedis
Any tibial revascularization is better than none
Intact pedal arch improves indirect revascularization success
Evidence mixed; consider but don't mandate angiosome targeting

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
